Exploring the Map of Everything with AI: A Guide for Curious Minds

What is the Map of Everything (MOE)?
Imagine every word or concept as a destination on a vast map.
This map is interconnected: between any two points (words or ideas) lies a whole unexplored territory filled with new knowledge and perspectives.
You navigate this map with your words, asking AI to reveal the connections and spaces between known ideas, leading to new discoveries.
Dialogue-Driven Exploration:
Just like a GPS guides you through unknown roads, AI (like chatGPT) guides you through this knowledge map.
Your conversation with AI is key: your questions and topics act as coordinates.
An example: By creating a virtual panel of diverse pedagogical experts (as if they were points on the map), you can explore different educational theories and perspectives, deepening your understanding.
Applying the Framework:
This approach is not just theoretical; you can practice it using chatGPT or similar AI platforms.
An upcoming chat-based version on WhatsApp will make this even more accessible.
Start with your interests or school subjects, ask chatGPT to explore related ideas, and see where the conversation leads.
The goal is to expand your thinking, discover new connections, and develop your unique perspective.
Creative Contribution:
As you explore, you're not just a traveler but also a map-maker, adding your insights to the MOE.
Each new idea or connection you make is like adding a new coordinate to the map, enriching it for others.
Encouraging Curiosity and Critical Thinking:
This method is all about asking the right questions, not just looking for straightforward answers.
It encourages you to think critically, make connections, and approach learning as an exciting journey of discovery.
Example Prompts to Get You Started:

"What is the connection between climate change and economic policies?"
"Explore the differing views on digital privacy in various cultures."
"What would a debate between historical figures about modern technology look like?"
Remember, the journey of knowledge is endless, and with the Map of Everything, you have the power to explore it in ways never before possible. Let your curiosity be your compass!

S.C.R.I.B.E.R Like You‚Äôre Five
Prompt Techniques to Help You Think Yourself
Welcome, Young Explorer!
Our world is like a huge puzzle, and sometimes, figuring things out can be a bit tricky. But guess what? You have a special map called the "Map of Everything" (or MOE) to help you! MOE is like a magic guide that knows lots of things and can help you ask questions you never thought of!
Your S.C.R.I.B.E Adventure Map
Seek (Find New Things)
Be Like: An explorer looking for treasure.
Adventure Tip: Ask MOE questions like "Who knows about stars?" or "How do airplanes stay up?"
Critique (Learn from Answers)
Be Like: A detective solving a mystery.
Adventure Tip: Ask MOE why things are the way they are, like "Why do we sleep at night?"
Reflect (Think About What You Learn)
Be Like: A thinker making up stories.
Adventure Tip: After MOE tells you something, draw a picture or write a story about it.
Inquire (Ask More Questions)
Be Like: A curious cat asking "why?" you may find hidden doors in a castle!
Adventure Tip: Ask MOE to explain things, like "Why is the grass green?"
Broaden/Contract (Look Wide, Choose One)
Be Like: A chef choosing ingredients.
Adventure Tip: Ask MOE for different ideas, then pick your favorite, like choosing a flavor of ice cream!
Explain (Understand the Answers)
Be Like: A teacher learning new things.
Adventure Tip: Ask MOE why it gives certain answers, like "Why do you think the sky is blue?"
Understanding: You're learning the secrets behind MOE's magic!
Recurse (Keep Asking Back and Forth)
Be Like: Playing a game of catch with questions.
Adventure Tip: Ask MOE a question, and then MOE asks you back, like "What's your favorite animal? Now, what's MOE's?"
Remember, Young Explorer!
You don't need to remember all these steps; just have fun exploring with MOE. It's not about following a map perfectly; it's about going on an exciting adventure and discovering new things along the way!
Ready for Your S.C.R.I.B.E Adventure?
Grab your Map of Everything, and let's go find some amazing treasures of knowledge!



S.C.R.I.B.E.R For Adults
Prompt Techniques to Help You Think Yourself
Introduction
Artificial intelligence is changing the world of work. Some people are getting great results, and some find LLMs, like chatGPT, fun yet useless for ‚Äúthe real world of work.‚Äù The opportunity is there, yet it requires us to learn how LLMs work, and from there, we will be able to get better results.
In a nutshell, LLMs store knowledge in a graph representing ideas in space. By speaking to it, you move around in this graph. Once you‚Äôre somewhere in the graph, you can ask it what is around you that you ‚Äúcan‚Äôt see.‚Äù 
This framework will allow you to use chatGPT and other LLMs to help you think, not think for you. We developed these principles to help you experience this intuition about how LLMs operate and to teach you that you can now, perhaps for the first time in history, teach yourself the things you don‚Äôt even know you don‚Äôt know.
May you wield this tool well and create great benefits for yourself, your communities, and the world.
The S.C.R.I.B.E.R Framework for Prompting
Seek: Exploring your gaps in different domains of knowledge.
Critique: Actively seek constructive critique from antagonist personas.
Reflect: Procedurally review the LLM‚Äôs work and create tools to think with.
Inquire: Ask the AI to ask you questions to help it navigate to new spaces.
Broaden/Contract: Seek gaps. Ask the LLM for non-overlapping options and pick.
Explain: Ask LLM to share its reasoning for transparency and corrections.
Recurse: Ask the LLM to ask it to ask you to ask it.

The following table shares the SCRIBE Framework in three parts.
Principles are ideas that you keep it in mind and attempt to act upon them.
Techniques are how you can apply the principles. It‚Äôs just one method of many.
The Way of Being is a quality of presence from which the principles and techniques can emerge. It can be cultivated by repeated practice of the techniques and deep reflection on the principles. It is what matters in the end.

Note: Do NOT memorize this list. 
These techniques and principles are tools to help us embody the knowledge. Aim to have a mindset of using LLMs as a tool for thought. 
Experts don't recite steps; they embody their knowledge. Imagine a chef constantly looking up recipes! It's not about following a checklist; it's about making the knowledge a part of who you are. It‚Äôs from here that new principles and techniques will emerge. 
The ultimate goal of learning is to become.
